newsitem.title: BELARUS: Belarus to continue grain imports.
newsitem.headline: Belarus to continue grain imports.

text.p: Belarus plans to import 200,000 tonnes of wheat and 600,000-700,000 tonnes of other grains and pulses in 1997, Deputy Agriculture Minister Ivan Shakolo said on Tuesday.
Belarus has traditionally imported from neighbouring former Soviet republics such as Russia and Ukraine.
"Belarus intends to import 200,000 tonnes of wheat and 600,000 to 700,000 tonnes of other grains and peas in 1997," Shakolo told a news conference. He did not specify origins.
The former Soviet republic has forecast a 6.5 million tonne grain harvest against 5.8 million tonnes in 1996.
It imported 500,000 tonnes of grains last year.
Shakolo also said winter grain yields stood at 3.0 tonnes per hectare compared to 2.7 tonnes per hectare last year.
"Our winter grains did very well through the winter and received enough inputs, and maybe three to four percent didn't make it, which is usual," he said.
About 33.7 percent of spring sowing was complete, he added, and yields of 2.7 to 2.8 tonnes per hectare were expected.
Belarus would increase wheat sowing to 80,300 hectares from 54,600 hectares last year and planned to produce 900,000 tonnes of wheat from 600,000 tonnes in 1996, he added.
"In upcoming years we plan to increase sowing areas and to bring yields to 3.5 to 3.7 tonnes per hectare, so that we can fully meet our own domestic needs," Shakolo said.
